newsitem.title: UK: EU majority against stability council - UK official.
newsitem.headline: EU majority against stability council - UK official.

text.p: A senior British official said a clear majority of European Union countries opposed suggestions that a "stability council" comprised of government representatives should serve as a political counter-weight to a European central bank in monetary policy.
"I am deeply suspicious and so are about two thirds of member states," the official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. "A clear majority of member states is deeply resistant to all that."
French President Jacques Chirac has called for a political body to counterbalance the European central bank when a single currency is created.
The official said Britain firmly opposed suggestions that an independent European central bank responsible for setting monetary policy should be subject to political control.

He said more discussion was needed within the EU to ensure "the basic political infrastructure of the Union is not adversely affected by the division which is inevitably going to take place between the members of the euro zone and the rest."
Any division into "first and second-class membership" of the EU would be worrying but would be quite difficult to avoid.
"The British will be resistant to that, whether we imagine divisive and it should not be allowed," the official added.
